section.title: Grammatical function tags
section.p: Our syntactic tags (grammatical function tags like @SUBJ, @OBJ, etc.) are based upon a compromise between the Sámi grammatical tradition and the conventions used within constraint grammar (CG), e.g. as found in visl project for interactive syntax learning. The main difference between the two is that CG is a linear system, where tags are given to wordforms, and not to phrases. Thus, in a sentence like the Sámi equivalent of Peter's dog barks only the word dog will get the tag @SUBJ. The word Peter's gets the tag @>N, or "modifying a noun to its right". It is then up to the reader (or to further computer processing) to interpret the combination of @>N and @SUBJ as a phrase.

The arrow in a syntactic tag points at the "parent", which means that the tag tells which kind of part of speech (N, A, P, Pron or Num) or syntactic constituent (like ADVL) the wordform modifies or is a complement to, and if the "parent" is to the left of to the right.

Note that all syntactic tags are identified by an initial @ symbol, to distinguish them from morphological tags, which do not have such a prefix. In the analysis, the syntactic tags are printed at the end of the tag string.

section.title: The syntactic tags for Sami
section.p: The Sámi disambiguation file sme-dis.rle adds syntactic tags to each cohort.

section.title: The verb tags
section.p: These tags are self-explanatory: there are finite and infinite main and auxiliary verbs.

section.title: The major function tags
section.p: The four main functions for subject, object and their predicatives are obvious. Also in habitative phrases we will have subject: beana gets @SUBJ in Máhtes lea beana. The argument for this solution, is that beana congruates with the verbal, so we get Máhtes leat beatnagat.

These are tags for the same functions of infinite verbs outside the verbal: mu gets @-FSUBJ in Diet dáhpáhuvai mu dieđikeahttá (the infinite verb gets @ADVL) and girjji gets @-FOBJ in Munnje lei lossat lohkat girjji. (the infinite verb gets @SPRED).

section.title: The adverbial tags
section.p: The @ADVL tag marks adverbials (many, but not all of the adverbials are adverbs). The adverbial of an infinite verb outside the verbal gets @-FADVL. The @HAB tag marks the habitative construction.
The @PCLE tag marks particles, and the @COMPL-CS< tag is for the complement of a @CS.
The two tags @>P and @P< are for complements of post- and prepositions, respectively.
The two tags @>ADVL and @ADVL< modify the adverbial to the right or is a complement of the adverbial to the left.

section.title: The NP-internal modifiers
section.p: The other syntactic tags for modifiers tell which word they modify, and if it is to the left or to the right.
The morphological tag will tell what kind of part of speech the constituent itself is.
The @Pron< tag is for eg. numerals modifying pronouns to their left, like in Mii golmmas finaimet máná geahčen.
The @Q< tag is for complements for quantifiers, like máná in Sudnos leat golbma máná.

section.title: Appositions
section.p: The apposition tag marks if it is an apposition of a noun, a pronoun, a numeral or an adverbial.
